newsitem.title: ABU DHABI: SOCCER-SAUDI ARABIA TO FACE UAE IN ASIAN CUP FINAL.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-SAUDI ARABIA TO FACE UAE IN ASIAN CUP FINAL.

text.p: Favourites Saudi Arabia won a penalty-shootout 4-3 against triple champions Iran on Wednesday to book an Asian Cup final showdown with hosts the United Arab Emirates who beat Kuwait 1-0.
Defender Ahmed Madani scored the decisive goal to silence the 15,000 Iranian supporters and send the Saudis to their fourth final in a row.
The final will be played on Saturday.
Iran striker Ali Daei, the tournament's top scorer with seven goals, missed the target with the first kick of the shootout and left the field in tears.
The score was 3-3 after five kicks each. Mohammad Al Daeyea then saved Mohammad Khakpour's attempt before Madani hit the winner.
The Saudis went close to winning the game in the second half of normal time, hitting the crossbar twice, the second time in the 89th minute.
A superb save by Iran keeper Nima Nakisa from a header by substitute Abdullah Al Dossary denied the Saudis a ''golden goal'' in the 24th minute of extra time.
It was sweat revenge for the Saudis who were hammered 3-0 by the Iranians in a group phase tie last week.
Saudi Arabia won the title in 1984 and 1988 but lost to Japan in the final four years ago. Iran won the title three times back-to-back between 1968 and 1976.

Thousands of locals took to the streets after the final whistle of the UAE-Kuwait match to celebrate their team's surprise qualification for the final. The UAE had never previously reached the final in the competition's 40-year history.
Striker Hassan Ahmed rose to head in a corner 21 minutes from time against the run of play to give the hosts victory.
The match was marked by two controversial decisions by Japanese referee Okada Masayoshi who twice booked UAE players for off-the-ball incidents against Kuwaiti players.
Kuwait on both occassions protested that the offenders should have been sent off.
A controversial refereeing decision against Kuwait had also marked the meeting between the two teams 10 days ago in the group stage. The UAE also won that match 3-2.
UAE captain Adnan Al-Talyani was lucky to stay on the field in the 56th minute when he elbowed Jamal Abdulrahman as the players waited for a Kuwaiti corner.
The Japanese referee, who did not see the incident, produced only the yellow card to Talyani after consulting his linesman.
The referee had also showed the yellow card to UAE's Hassan Mubarak for another off-the-ball incident in the 44th minute.
The two losing teams take part in a playoff for third place on Saturday ahead of the final.
